body: we will need the input files to reproduce and debug it

An example is 2f2h protein.pdb of the refined dataset pdbbind.
I have observed, that sometimes a restart of the script can help but not every time. Mostly the problem raises at big proteins. For all but one times I get this error, the protein had over 50k atoms.

One can solve this, by deleting some atoms. So for example prot.filter('Some_Cutoff'). But I would say, that this can not be the optimal solution.

I have also tested my memory. The hardware seems OK.

Thank you for the information.
Could you give an example? Maybe for 1a1e which is Linked in issue #12.

Actually I do Not directly understand what you mean.
Ich have to pay attention to do not delete any Atom in the box. And it sounds like i have to Filter manually the chains for all the complexes, because the chains are different. Right?

Did you can give a reason, why a chain-selection is netter than a cutoff?
Actually I have a boxsize of 24 and Cut Off all atoms which are more 60 angstrom in distance to the ligand center. So I would think far away. But maybe I have a mistake in my theory.

PS. Sorry for the bad english. German autocorrection... I gave up after the 3. sentence

So from what I read here and in the other issue it sounds like you haven't done much preprocessing. 

Things you should do before actually applying the voxelization procedure are:
* filter unnecessary ions or molecules out of the structure
* run the `proteinPrepare` procedure of moleculekit to adjust the protonation state and also to filter alternative sidechain conformers in the files
* remove unnecessary protein chains, if your ligand is in chain A you don't really care about the other chains

This should also resolve your issue with Selenium in the other issue. So before voxelizing and using the data as is, be aware of common issues with crystallographic data/models and clean the data to your needs.

Well

The filtering of unnecessary ions and molecules can be done with 

Mol.filter('protein') 

Right?
I always do this.

Also the proteinprepare function I always use as second step.

As mentioned in the other ticket, this leads in some ways to errors, which I show in Ticket #12. Also the selenium error raises after filtering of protein and preperation function.

The filtering of the Chain seems problematic. I would assume, that the ligand is not always in the same chain. So it seems like, I have to filter this for every molecule manually. For around 4k complexes this seems not doable. Did you know a method, how one can do this automatically?
Maybe this could be the last trick.
Also, does it not change the chemical properties of the molecule, if one is filtering out some sidechains? 
I would expect a big influence on the chemical properties, the voxel-features and also on the binding behavior. But I do not know. This is just a rough assumption. What is your opinion to this?

Is there any case, in which the deactivation of validitychecks is a good idea? 

Nevetheless. In some cases the ligand has for example 5 bonds for a carbon. The converting with autodock can fix this, but nobody knows, if the result is the experimental ligand and in the worst but not unprobable case, the fixed ligand is wrong and the binding affinity does not match to the complex anymore. It seems, that this could be a problem and could lead to a bias in a CNN. 
But this is just a really rough assumption and thats why I am sceptical if this is a good idea. 
But this is another Problem, which is not part of this ticket.

The protein preparation will indeed move some stuff around a bit but not too significantly I would say. You need it mostly if your proteins are missing the hydrogens as there is no other way to get them. Unless you want to do KDeep without any hydrogens (but make sure you remove them all) which is an option. Might even work.

Filtering out alternative locations of sidechains is not really an issue as there should not be any in this dataset

As for modifying the ligands the only other option is to write to the maintainers of the database to clarify issues with their ligands which could take some time, or having a legit chemist in the lab who can tell you how it should be.

Ah well. Sure i know the difference about sidechains and chains. But I did not expect, that there are chains which do not have any atom in a specific range around the ligand. But there are. In this case, maybe you are right and it could be a better option, to no destroy the chains, which are close to the ligand. Your method deletes less atoms than my. Which is always good.
Thank you for this point. I did not see this.

For KDeep I would try both. For deleting the hydrogens, one could use the filter-function. Right?

I have wrote them. If they bring a solution, I try this. If not, I would use AutoDock or an reduced dataset without the broken.

Maybe in this case, the ticket can be closed from my side. The SIGSEGV-error is something more complicated I think. The only solution here is, to reduce the number of atoms.

I replicated the segfault and found the cause. The cause is this issue which we have already reported to openbabel https://github.com/openbabel/openbabel/issues/1955
Practically larger protein structures will segfault when being read in with openbabel. Nothing we can do other than wait for them to fix the issue or reduce the number of atoms.

issue.title: Error in Molecule and Smallmol while working with PDBBind dataset

repository.name: moleculekit
repository.description: MoleculeKit: Your favorite molecule manipulation kit

issue.body:
I was trying to voxelize the PDBBind complexes with moleculekit but for most of the complexes, Moleculekit is throwing errors while building the `Molecule` or `SmallMol` object. Here is my code:

```python
from moleculekit.molecule import Molecule
from moleculekit.tools.voxeldescriptors import getVoxelDescriptors, viewVoxelFeatures
from moleculekit.tools.atomtyper import prepareProteinForAtomtyping
from moleculekit.smallmol.smallmol import SmallMol
from moleculekit.home import home
import os

data_dir = "../../dataset/refined-set-2016"
protein_files = sorted(glob('../../dataset/refined-set-2016/*/*protein.pdb'))
ligand_files = sorted(glob('../../dataset/refined-set-2016/*/*ligand.mol2'))

for p, l in zip(protein_files, ligand_files):
    try:
        prot = Molecule(p)
        ligand = SmallMol(l)
    except Exception as e:
        print(str(e))
```

Here is the error
```
Failed to read file ../../dataset/refined-set-2016/2cli/2cli_ligand.mol2. Try by setting the force_reading option as True.
```

Is there any workaround? I want to voxelize all the complexes after building the `Molecule` and `SmallMol` object
